_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority (PRASA) System has develop a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for management and prevention of risks associated with the storage and use of chlorine, a regulated toxic substance, at Puerto Nuevo WWTP. The RMP was prepared in compliance with 40 CFR Part 68 and Clean Air Act (CAA) Section 112(1). The Prevention Porgram Elements build upon the facility's Process Safety Management (PSM) System prepared in compliance with 29 CFR 1910.119.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

It is PRASA's policy to comply with applicable Federal and Puerto Rico requirements. The disinfection process at the Puerto Nuevo RWWTP uses chlorine, a hazardous toxic substance regulated by EPA, OSHA, PROSHO and EQB. Due to the hazardous characteristics of chlorine, the Puerto Nuevo RWWTP observes various safety precautions in the storage, conveyance and use of chlorine. The safety precautions are necessary to protect employees, contractors, and visitors at the Puerto Nuevo RWWTP and the immediate surrounding areas. Safety precautions include procedures and equipment to minimize the potential for accidental release as well as a written emergency response program for response to any chlorine release that may occur.

The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The Puerto Nuevo RWWTP outfall terminates in a high-rate diffuser located in the Atlantic Ocean approximately 3,600 feet offshore north of Isla de Cabras that discharges into the Atlantic Ocean. Chlorine is used to treat the water in order to eliminate objectionable odors.

Chlorine is delivered to the facility via truck in ton containers. The maximum inventory of chlorine is 100,000 pounds. Chlorine containers are connected to vacuum chlorinators, a system that regulates vacuum and chlorine flow in the system.

Prevention Program

The Prevention Program is composed of many elements and its objective is to prevent accidents and protect the human health, the environmen

t and the property.

Emergency Response Program

PRASA has an emergency response program. Chlorine gas detectors are located within the storage area for early detection and warning of any leak. Leak repair kits are maintained on site, and operators are trained in how to quickly stop any leak that may occur. The emergency response program is coordinated with Civil Defense for notification of the public. PRASA periodically conducts various training programs, including emergency response training.

Five-year Accident History

Within the past five years there have been no unplanned releases of chlorine in excess of 10 pounds resulting in injuries or significant property damage on site; or known offsite injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

PRASA uses Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) to identify and recommend changes to ensure a high level of safety. Issues identified from a PHA are then adderessed in PRASA's Prevention Program. Recommendations from the most recent PHA Iinclude more frequent training in operating and maintenance procedures, and an improved preventative maintenance program.
